Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Novel Control Strategy for 3D Printing of Micro-Scale Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive manufacturing systems, often called 3D printers, are poised to displace conventional manufacturing operations in many meso-scale applications (parts from 1 to 100 millimeters in size). Similarly, 3D printing at the micro-scale (from 0.001 to 0.1 millimeters in size) has the potential to revolutionize the way that biological and chemical sensors and integrated circuits are prototyped and manufactured. 3D printers build up complex parts by depositing one thin layer of material at a time. Electrohydrodynamic jet, or e-jet, printing is a promising micro-scale version of this process. This project will add sensors to a standard e-jet printer, and apply an innovative control law to greatly improve the precision of the resulting parts. The control law is based on the observation that 3D printed features typically change very little from one layer to the next. By observing how a layer deviates from its desired shape, the baseline e-jet control can be modified to improve the accuracy of the next layer. In this project, an atomic force microscope will be integrated with an e-jet printer to measure the shape of each layer. To better correct the printing process, the electric field around each layer will also be measured. The technical research plan is integrated with educational outreach to initiate undergraduate "micro-maker" clubs and catalyze an open-source, bottom-up movement based on inexpensive ink-jet printing of custom microcircuits and sensors.

Micro-scale Additive Manufacturing, and in particular, electrohydrodynamic jet printing, has the potential to revolutionize 3D, functional, micro-scale device fabrication. Limiting this step change in manufacturing capabilities is the reliance of micro-scale Additive Manufacturing systems on a process monitoring, regulation, and quality control paradigm that is performed post-process and in an ad hoc manner. This research will break this open-loop paradigm by generating fundamental scientific knowledge in two areas: 1) the synthesis of a controls theoretic framework to compensate for spatial disturbances with a robust and computationally efficient learning-based algorithm and 2) the study of interactions between charged jets of materials and substrates in electrohydrodynamic jet printing using first principles physics models and validated by empirical studies leveraging a novel integration of electrohydrodynamic jet printing and atomic force microscopy. This research will contribute the fundamental knowledge required to transform 3D micro-scale Additive Manufacturing from a nascent, open-loop and ad hoc technology set to a fully automated, accurate, and robust closed-loop system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major Goals: The objectives of the research project were to: 1) (Intellectual Merit 1 (IM1)) explore new scientific knowledge in spatial iterative learning control (SILC) to enable the fabrication of the complex architecture fabrication of microscale functional devices and do so in a robust way that can compensate for process variability and 2) (IM2) describe a general framework for input parameter learning in manufacturing systems that have spatial dynamics.  Broader Impact 1 (BI1): The intended application for such work was microscale additive manufacturing (u-AM), a class of layer-by-layer manufacturing systems that allow complex, graded topographies at the microscale; u-AM can be used to fabricate function microdevices such as sensors, biological arrays, and microactuators and switches.

 Major Activities: One PhD graduate student, Zhi Wang, has been focused on the project since project commencement. Mr. Wang has led three major investigations: 1) a reformulation of Iterative Learning Control (ILC) that uses spatial coordinates instead of the typical temporal coordinates and the stability and convergence theory and experimental demonstration thereof; 2) (IM3) a framework for system identification for building an empirical understanding of material addition behavior in u-AM; and 3) (IM4) stability and monotonic convergence criteria for multi-layer fabrication in u-AM where layer-to-layer dynamics can become unstable (hills and valleys become more pronounced with each layer of manufacturing).  In conjunction with the team at the University of Michigan, the frameworks and theory have been integrated into a novel combined u-AM and atomic force microscopy (AFM) metrology system.  A complete set of experimental studies have validated the SILC framework and system identification framework for spatial systems.  Using SILC integrated into the u-AM/AFM system, we have demonstrated part-to-part feedback control of manufactured structure topographies.  This system has enabled us to build microdevices with contoured topographies.  (BI2) The ability to make structures with contoured topographies is a major departure from the planar manufacturing limitation of lithographic micromachining which is used to manufacture virtually all modern microdevices and integrated circuits.  This functionality opens up new microdevice design opportunities; potential applications include optical metamaterials with non-planar lenses, non-planar transistor elements, and continuously variable microfluidic channel dimensions for cell separation and assaying. 

Breakthroughs and Discoveries:

1) Formalized the SILC update law, stability and convergence criteria.  Stability and monotonic convergence criteria have been defined for both deterministic, known manufacturing dynamics and interval uncertain dynamics in which the system response is bounded by a vertex model.

2) Experimentally demonstrated the ability to co-register the u-AM frame-of-reference and AFM frame-of-reference, print sample parts, and automatically measure sample part topographies. 

3) Experimentally demonstrated the ability to empirically identify a model of spatial dynamics of u-AM printing via a system identification framework.  The framework identifies both the in-layer spatial dynamics and the dynamics that propagate from layer-to-layer. 

4) Experimentally demonstrated the SILC framework applied to the manufacture of microdevices.  Through active feedback of process inputs, we can make structures with contour topographies with resolutions on the order of that fabricated by lithographic micromachining (order of 1 um x- and y-axis resolution and order of 100 nm z-axis resolution); Figure 1 demonstrates three micro-topography designs (reference) and corresponding heat maps of the measured topography after 19 and 20 iterations of manufacturing feedback.  Process feedback is stable and convergent, as demonstrated by the traces of process errors (Figure 2) and the stability and convergence behavior can be predicted a priori from developed theory and an interval model of the identified process dynamics (Fig. 3, closed circles denote controller designs that satisfy a sufficient condition for robust monotonic convergence and open circles denote designs that do not satisfy this condition; designs near the sufficient condition boundary are experimentally verified to be convergent and the one design distant from the boundary diverges in experiment). 

 Dissemination: (BI3) Project efforts has led to three published journal papers with three additional journal papers currently under review and two more to be submitted in the next month.  Additionally, six conference papers have been published and one conference paper is under review.  The PI or members of the group have highlighted work from this project in six conference presentations or poster sessions and five invited talks.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Major Goals: The objectives of the research project were to: 1) (Intellectual Merit 1 (IM1)) explore new scientific knowledge in spatial iterative learning control (SILC) to enable the fabrication of the complex architecture fabrication of microscale functional devices and do so in a robust way that can compensate for process variability and 2) (IM2) describe a general framework for input parameter learning in manufacturing systems that have spatial dynamics. Broader Impact 1 (BI1): The intended application for such work was microscale additive manufacturing (u-AM), a class of layer-by-layer manufacturing systems that allow complex, graded topographies at the microscale; u-AM can be used to fabricate function microdevices such as sensors, biological arrays, and microactuators and switches. Major Activities: One PhD graduate student, Zhi Wang, has been focused on the project since project commencement. Mr. Wang has led three major investigations: 1) a reformulation of Iterative Learning Control (ILC) that uses spatial coordinates instead of the typical temporal coordinates and the stability and convergence theory and experimental demonstration thereof; 2) (IM3) a framework for system identification for building an empirical understanding of material addition behavior in u-AM; and 3) (IM4) stability and monotonic convergence criteria for multi-layer fabrication in u-AM where layer-to-layer dynamics can become unstable (hills and valleys become more pronounced with each layer of manufacturing). In conjunction with the team at the University of Michigan, the frameworks and theory have been integrated into a novel combined u-AM and atomic force microscopy (AFM) metrology system. A complete set of experimental studies have validated the SILC framework and system identification framework for spatial systems. Using SILC integrated into the u-AM/AFM system, we have demonstrated part-to-part feedback control of manufactured structure topographies. This system has enabled us to build microdevices with contoured topographies. (BI2) The ability to make structures with contoured topographies is a major departure from the planar manufacturing limitation of lithographic micromachining which is used to manufacture virtually all modern microdevices and integrated circuits. This functionality opens up new microdevice design opportunities; potential applications include optical metamaterials with non-planar lenses, non-planar transistor elements, and continuously variable microfluidic channel dimensions for cell separation and assaying. Breakthroughs and Discoveries: 1) Formalized the SILC update law, stability and convergence criteria. Stability and monotonic convergence criteria have been defined for both deterministic, known manufacturing dynamics and interval uncertain dynamics in which the system response is bounded by a vertex model. 2) Experimentally demonstrated the ability to co-register the u-AM frame-of-reference and AFM frame-of-reference, print sample parts, and automatically measure sample part topographies. 3) Experimentally demonstrated the ability to empirically identify a model of spatial dynamics of u-AM printing via a system identification framework. The framework identifies both the in-layer spatial dynamics and the dynamics that propagate from layer-to-layer. 4) Experimentally demonstrated the SILC framework applied to the manufacture of microdevices. Through active feedback of process inputs, we can make structures with contour topographies with resolutions on the order of that fabricated by lithographic micromachining (order of 1 um x- and y-axis resolution and order of 100 nm z-axis resolution); Figure 1 demonstrates three micro-topography designs (reference) and corresponding heat maps of the measured topography after 19 and 20 iterations of manufacturing feedback. Process feedback is stable and convergent, as demonstrated by the traces of process errors (Figure 2) and the stability and convergence behavior can be predicted a priori from developed theory and an interval model of the identified process dynamics (Fig. 3, closed circles denote controller designs that satisfy a sufficient condition for robust monotonic convergence and open circles denote designs that do not satisfy this condition; designs near the sufficient condition boundary are experimentally verified to be convergent and the one design distant from the boundary diverges in experiment). Dissemination: (BI3) Project efforts has led to three published journal papers with three additional journal papers currently under review and two more to be submitted in the next month. Additionally, six conference papers have been published and one conference paper is under review. The PI or members of the group have highlighted work from this project in six conference presentations or poster sessions and five invited talks.
